resource.description: The main objective is to create safe and useful artifact analysis environment, based on current best practices.
resource.title: Building artefact handling and analysis environment

resource.description: Present the trainees various methods of malicious artifacts acquisition with emphasis on artifacts collected through spam e-mails monitoring. Teach how to correctly set up spam collecting environment and simple artifacts repository. Exercise also provides knowledge how to modify and patch created system to better suit lab environment needs.
resource.title: Processing and storing artefacts

resource.description: Present the trainees malicious artifact analysis fundamentals and various types of analyses. Present how to safely execute suspicious code in the controlled environment along with most important security precautions.
resource.title: Artefact analysis fundamentals

resource.description: Teach students how to obtain memory images from different sources and to analyse them. Both Windows and Linux systems will be covered.
resource.title: Advanced artefact handling

resource.description: This three-day training module will follow the tracks of an incident handler and investigator, teaching best practices and covering both sides of the breach. It is technical in nature and has the aim to provide a guided training for both incident handlers and investigators while providing lifelike conditions. Training material mainly uses open source and free tools.
resource.title: Forensic analysis: Local Incident Response

resource.description: The main goal of this training is to teach trainees network forensic techniques and extend trainees operating system forensic capabilities beyond Microsoft Windows systems to include Linux. Trainees will follow traces in the workstation and discover that analysed network captures together with logs, lead to another machine on the network.
resource.title: Forensic analysis: Network Incident Response

resource.description: This training requires the students to perform a forensic analysis of three (web) servers, identified during the first two exercises as taking part in a malicious campaign.
resource.title: Forensic analysis: Webserver Analysis

resource.description: Learn how to leverage information gathered during analysis into actionable signatures. Both network and system oriented signatures will be discussed.
resource.title: Developing countermeasures

resource.description: Learn how to collect, store and correlate different types of information about samples and how to make use of this information with the assumption that having a structured and organised database is a good way to reaching synergy in the area of artifact analysis and incident investigation.
resource.title: Common framework for artefact analysis activities

resource.description: This training presents the introduction to the advanced artefact analysis. It is the first part of a three-day course introducing assembly language and tools commonly used for the advanced artefact analysis.
resource.target_audience: CSIRT staff and incident handlers involved in the technical analysis of incidents.
resource.title: Introduction to advanced artefact analysis

resource.description: This training presents methods and techniques of dynamic artefact analysis with the use of OllyDbg debugger package.
resource.target_audience: CSIRT staff and incident handlers involved in the technical analysis of incidents.
resource.title: Dynamic analysis of artefacts

resource.description: The goal of this training is to introduce the participants to all aspects of static artefact analysis.
resource.target_audience: CSIRT staff and incident handlers involved in the technical analysis of incidents.
resource.title: Static analysis of artefacts

resource.description: Present the trainees various methods of malicious artifacts acquisition with emphasis on artifacts collected through spam e-mails monitoring. Teach how to correctly set up spam collecting environment and simple artifacts repository. Exercise also provides knowledge how to modify and patch created system to better suit lab environment needs.
resource.title: Processing and storing artefacts

resource.description: Learn how to create and deploy indicators of compromise using Collaborative Research into Threats (CRITs) platform. Additionally, demonstrate how to leverage CRITs to visualize relationships among different elements of a campaign, how to extract indicators from incident data, develop mitigation actions, and track those actions.
resource.title: Using indicators to enhance defence capabilities

resource.description: Present the trainees with the principles of evidence gathering. Establish a common knowledge of the requirements regarding evidence admissibility in a court of law. This task also gives an overview of popular malware characteristics, methods of identification and tools that may be used at the scene.
resource.title: Identification and handling of electronic evidence

resource.description: Present the trainees with the principles of digital forensics and evidence gathering.
resource.title: Digital forensics

resource.description: Setting up and working with AbuseHelper.
resource.title: Proactive incident detection

resource.description: Make the students familiar with special requirements and tools to do incident handling and forensics with mobile/smartphone computing platforms.
resource.title: Mobile threats incident handling

resource.description: The goal of this training is to introduce the threats found in mobile environment, and to familiarise the participants with various tools and techniques used in Mobile Forensics and Incident Handling.
resource.target_audience: CSIRT staff and incident handlers involved in the technical analysis of incident.
resource.title: Mobile threats Incident handling (Part II)

resource.description: The purpose of this task is to develop students’ abilities to create custom scripts and filters dealing with large amounts of data such as IP addresses. After completing the exercise students should be able to extract useful information from bulk data, even in non-standard formats.
resource.title: Automation in incident handling

files: Toolset Ex1Toolset Ex2Toolset Ex3Virtual Image 1Virtual Image 2Virtual Image 3Virtual Image 4
resource.description: The training materials are based on good practices, and include all needed methodologies, tools and procedures. The training includes the performance indicators and means, supporting those who use it to increase their operational competence. It is made available in a ready-to use version.  The training consists of an extensive introduction (sections 1–4) and three exercises (section 5). The updated scenarios also include content that is in line with the current technologies and methodologies.
resource.target_audience: CSIRT staff and incident handlers involved in the technical analysis of incident.
resource.title: Introduction to network forensics

resource.description: Familiarise students with two kinds of honeypots: server-side honeypots and client-side honeypots.
resource.title: Honeypots

resource.description: To provide a practical overview of the vulnerability handling process and how vulnerabilities reported to a CERT team should be handled. Also, to provide some hands-on experience with difficult situations that may arise through the role of coordinator.
resource.title: Vulnerability handling

resource.description: Technical aspects of using visualisation to present, correlate and filter various feeds. The scenario will also cover the organisational aspects. In this scenario the students will be part of the CERT for a fictitious organisation which is analysing cybercrime activities.
resource.title: Presenting, correlating and filtering various feeds

resource.description: Make CERT members aware of requirements during incident handling in CII/SCADA environments.
resource.target_audience: Incident handlers, incident management staff, technical CERT staff.
resource.title: Incident handling during an attack on Critical Information Infrastructure

resource.description: This task provides students with information about methods commonly used by attackers during the Advanced Persistent Threat (APT) attacks as well as methods of discovering and protecting internal resources against these attacks. Examples used in the exercise are based on real incidents and observations. The objective is also to involve participants in creative approaches to building CERT capability to deal effectively with and resolve the problem of APT attacks within an organisation.
resource.target_audience: Incident handlers and technical CERT staff.
resource.title: Advanced Persistent Threat incident handling

resource.description: In this task, participants will investigate the vulnerabilities of social networks, using an Advanced Persistent Threat scenario as a test case to illustrate some examples of social network compromises. They will also examine the capabilities of social networks to respond to these kinds of threats.
resource.target_audience: Incident handlers and technical CERT staff.
resource.title: Social networks used as an attack vector for targeted attacks

resource.description: The objective of the exercise is to provide a practical overview of what constitutes a good and a bad advisory publication for a CERT constituency.
resource.title: Writing Security Advisories

resource.description: Make the CERT team familiar with one solution for estimating the costs of different information security incidents.
resource.target_audience: Managers of CERT staff, incident handlers who have to estimate losses.
resource.title: Cost of ICT incident

resource.description: Simulate a real-life incident, involving many parties with conflicts of interests, different mindsets and legal frameworks, etc. With the introduction of such aspects as vulnerability handling, responsible disclosure and company security management, it helps the students to understand why incident handling is, in many cases, a complex task and what kinds of technical and social skills are required for this job.
resource.title: Incident handling in live role playing

resource.description: Investigate methods to address cloud-based security vulnerabilities through a scenario where data is not always fixed to one physical server or location.
resource.target_audience: Incident responders of all experience levels.
resource.title: Incident handling in the cloud

resource.description: Teach incident handlers the key information and actions required for the successful resolution of large-scale incidents.
resource.title: Large scale incident handling

resource.description: This exercise provides students with experience of real-life incident reports, their ambiguity and complexity. After completing the exercise, they should understand:
resource.target_audience: The exercise is aimed at incident handlers at any level of experience. It requires a good understanding of Internet topology and services.
resource.title: Incident Handling Management

resource.description: This training sets out to provide an indication of what an organisation might consider during the recruitment of staff for CSIRT teams.
resource.target_audience: The training is aimed at CSIRT managers who are responsible for recruiting staff.
resource.title: Recruitment of CSIRT staff

resource.description: To learn what kind of software and hardware solutions could be used to provide a particular CSIRT service for a constituency.
resource.title: Developing CSIRT infrastructure

resource.description: To enhance students’ skills in establishing contacts with other CERTs, administrators of ISPs, and other parties responsible for the mitigation of security incidents in their networks around the globe.
resource.title: Establishing external contacts

resource.description: Explain a CERT’s role in advising in a cyber-crime case and the basis for its effective cooperation with an LEA.
resource.title: Cooperation with Law Enforcement Agencies - Advising in Cyber Crime Cases

resource.description: In this exercise, participants will discuss all fundamental concepts of the communication channels between CERTs and their constituents, other CERTs, law enforcement, management, public relations (PR), legal counsel, and all other stakeholders. Special attention is given to communications while under attack, and to the testing of communication channels as a means of safeguarding and improving them.
resource.target_audience: CERT incident responders of all experience levels.
resource.title: Assessing and Testing Communication Channels with CERTs and all their stakeholders

resource.description: This task consists of 3 components: finding relevant information related to cybercrime in social media channels (based on Twitter examples), finding relevant information on IRC channels and analysing legal aspects of Internet monitoring activities related to cybercrime identification. The main objective is to teach trainees how to set up the basic system for continuous monitoring and alerting of various sources of information in terms of effective detection and warning for their constituencies based on the content.
resource.title: Identifying and handling cyber-crime traces

resource.description: This task treats phishing on three levels: technical, organisational and legal. The purpose is to understand phishing campaigns better and understand how to resolve them in complex international contexts.
resource.target_audience: National CERTs, bank CERTs, CERTs for big companies or organisations.
resource.title: Incident handling and cooperation during phishing campaign

resource.description: This task covers three different cybercrime related cases. All of them involve investigatory and legal aspects, but each of them requires participants to analyse them from different perspectives. All cases involve very common incidents for CERTs and organisations that could lead to law enforcement actions and court cases. Cooperation among the various parties involved is therefore essential and is the goal of this exercise – rather than exploring the techniques involved.
resource.target_audience: Incident responders of all experience levels.
resource.title: Cooperation in the Area of Cybercrime

resource.description: Information about rules, procedures and best practice in handling incident related to obligation for internet service providers described in the Article 13a of the European Telecom Package.
resource.title: CERT participation in incident handling related to the Article 13a obligations

resource.description: Information about rules, procedures and best practices in incident handling related to personal data breaches. It is based on data breach notification requirements for the electronic communication sector introduced by the review of the ePrivacy Directive. The process of notification is parallel to normal incident handling process and it is part of it.
resource.title: CERT participation in incident handling related to the Article 4 obligations

resource.description:
Launching attack to exploit the buffer-overflow vulnerability using shellcode. Conducting experiments
         with several countermeasures.
resource.title: Buffer Overflow Vulnerability Lab

resource.description:
Using the return-to-libc technique to defeat the "non-executable stack" countermeasure of
         the buffer-overflow attack.
resource.title: Return-to-Libc Attack Lab

files: Checklist for Security of Setuid Programs
resource.description:
Launching attacks on privileged Set-UID root program. Risks of environment variables. Side effects of
        system().
resource.title: Environment Variable and Set-UID Lab

resource.description:
Exploiting the race condition vulnerability in privileged program. Conducting experiments with
         various countermeasures.
resource.title: Race Condition Vulnerability Lab

resource.description:
Exploiting the Dirty COW race condition vulnerability in Linux kernel 
         to gain the root privilege.
resource.title: Dirty COW Attack Lab

resource.description:
Exploiting the format string vulnerability to crash a program, steal sensitive information, or
         modify critical data.
resource.title: Format String Vulnerability Lab

resource.description: Launch attack to exploit the Shellshock vulnerability that is discovered in late 2014.
resource.title: Shellshock Vulnerability Lab

resource.description: Sniffing packets sent over the local network and spoofing various types of packets.
resource.title: Packet Sniffing and Spoofing Lab

resource.description:
Launching attacks to exploit the vulnerabilities of the TCP/IP protocol, including session hijacking,
      SYN flooding, TCP reset attacks, etc.
resource.title: TCP/IP Attack Lab

resource.description: Using the heartbleed attack to steal secrets from a remote server.
resource.title: Heartbleed Attack Lab (Ubuntu 12.04 VM only)

resource.description: Using several methods to conduct DNS pharming attacks on computers in a LAN environment.
resource.title: Local DNS Attack Lab

resource.description: Using the Kaminsky method to launch DNS cache poisoning attacks on remote DNS servers.
resource.title: Remote DNS Attack Lab

resource.description:
Writing a simple packet-filter firewall; playing with Linux's built-in firewall software and
        web-proxy firewall; experimenting with ways to evade firewalls.
resource.title: Firewall Exploration Lab

files: Sample VPN client and server programs (without encryption)
resource.description:
Implement a simple vpn program (client/server), and use it to
        bypass firewalls.
resource.title: Firewall Evasion Lab

files: Sample VPN client and server programs (without encryption)
Sample TLS client and server programs
resource.description:
Design and implement a transport-layer VPN system for Linux, using the TUN/TAP
            technologies. This project requires at least a month of time to finish, so it is good
            for final project.
resource.title: Virtual Private Network (VPN) Lab

resource.description:
Launching the cross-site scripting attack on a vulnerable web application. Conducting experiments
         with several countermeasures.
resource.title: Cross-site Scripting Attack Lab

resource.description:
Launching the cross-site request forgery attack on a vulnerable web application. Conducting experiments
         with several countermeasures.
resource.title: Cross-site Request Forgery Attack Lab

resource.description:
Launching the SQL-injection attack on a vulnerable web application. Conducting experiments
         with several countermeasures. This is a newly developed lab, different from the one
	 using Collabtive. This lab does not use Elgg; instead, it uses a web application developed by us.
resource.title: SQL Injection Attack Lab

resource.description: Launching attack to exploit the Meltdown vulnerability in Intel CPUs.
resource.title: Meltdown Attack Lab

resource.description: Launching attack to exploit the Spectre vulnerability in Intel CPUs.
resource.title: Spectre Attack Lab

resource.description:
Use MD5 collision attack to create two different programs that 
         have the same MD5 hash value.
resource.title: MD5 Collision Attack Lab

resource.description:
Write a program to implement the RSA algorithm, and use it to do encryption,
      decryption, signature generation and verification.
resource.title: RSA Public-Key Encryption and Signature Lab

resource.description: Explore the secret-key encryption and its applications using OpenSSL.
resource.title: Secret Key Encryption Lab

resource.description: Learn how to generate pseudo random numbers that are strong for security purposes.
resource.title: Pseudo Random Number Generation Lab

resource.description: Explore public-key cryptography, digital signature, certificate, and PKI using OpenSSL.
resource.title: Public-Key Infrastructure (PKI) Lab

resource.description: Explore public-key cryptography, digital signature, certificate, and PKI using OpenSSL.
resource.title: Public-Key Infrastructure (PKI) Lab

resource.description: Explore public-key cryptography, digital signature, certificate, and PKI using OpenSSL.
resource.title: Public-Key Infrastructure (PKI) Lab

resource.description: Explore public-key cryptography, digital signature, certificate, and PKI using OpenSSL.
resource.title: Public-Key Infrastructure (PKI) Lab

resource.description: Explore public-key cryptography, digital signature, certificate, and PKI using OpenSSL.
resource.title: Public-Key Infrastructure (PKI) Lab

resource.description: Explore public-key cryptography, digital signature, certificate, and PKI using OpenSSL.
resource.title: Public-Key Infrastructure (PKI) Lab

resource.description: Explore public-key cryptography, digital signature, certificate, and PKI using OpenSSL.
resource.title: Public-Key Infrastructure (PKI) Lab

resource.description: Explore public-key cryptography, digital signature, certificate, and PKI using OpenSSL.
resource.title: Public-Key Infrastructure (PKI) Lab

resource.description: Insert malicious code inside an existing Android app, and repackage it.
resource.title: Android Repackaging Lab

resource.description: Develop an OTA (Over-The-Air) package from scratch to root an Android device.
resource.title: Android Device Rooting Lab
